review_title: Graduate student for Department of Economics
pros: A great part about being a graduate student in economics, is that every student has the same stipend. This helps create less tension among the graduate students and discourages competition. Imagine going to celebrate the completion of a big exam, and half of the class goes to get dinner at the local steak house, while the other half can only afford a burger.
cons: Due to the size of the school, the graduate programs tend to attract smaller cohorts. This can be a problem if you like to meet a lot of different people.

review_title: Computer Lab Asst. and all other jobs - Incredible Opportunity for Self-Development while working in a caring community.
job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Best student job on-campus, working at a computer while studying. Basically getting paid to do what you would be doing otherwise. Supervisors are awesome. Techs are polite and friendly. Scheduling system is fantastic. The community is incredible. The University of Wyoming is an employer that goes out of their way to offer the most to those employed by them. The hiring process is a not terribly long or intense. Beautiful campus and friendly, down to earth people. For a rural area, it is a busy little place.
cons: The parking is atrocious. The winters are cold, so combine that with the bad parking - and it can be pretty miserable on the worst days. Also, some of the shifts for student positions are broken down to 1hr slots. Can be quite annoying to work split shifts or one hour slots.

pros: If you were willing to work there very long term (i.e. not a college student), there were some reasonable opportunities for promotion.  Also, free meal for each shift work.
cons:
I specifically worked in the Dining Center, and the work environment was the worst I have ever seen.  The hours were reasonable, so long as you only worked one shift at a time.  Often you would be forced to do labor that was difficult or painful.

However, the worst part was a disregard for common health and safety practices.  When you start in the dining center, you are required to read and sign to a book of rules of conduct.  In there is a list of physical symptoms for which you are required to call in sick - among them things like high fever, diarrhea, nausea, etc.  However, what they don't mention is that if you are sick for more than a couple of shifts they will remove you from all shifts (and give them away), in essence a firing.  Because many of the people there are poor, broke college students you are often faced with the choice of ignoring the agreement you signed, or risking upsetting the management.  The only way to combat it seems to be to get your medical records released directly to the management.

review_title: It's the Wild West as a staff member here
job_title: Systems Programmer, Senior in Laramie, WY
pros:
Excellent vacation policy for benefited employees - 14 hours a month, plus most school holidays and a one week winter holiday between Christmas and New Years. 
Great retirement contributions into your choice of a 401k or state pension plan
cons:
No leadership within Information Technology. Prime examples of this are the lack of a service management infrastructure (attempts to implement ITIL and other methodoligies have always failed to catch on permanently), and no software/application development process such as Agile or Waterfall in place. There are also no guidelines or institutional commitments to interaction between departments and IT. Many directors adopt a "get it done, and don't bother me" philosophy, and do not have a basic understanding of what the various teams in their departments are working on. Basic position descriptions of responsibilities, expectations, and accountability are not provided.

Office culture is generally a "backstabbing" environment, due to the lack of advancement opportunities and managerial support.

pros: Coming to Wyoming is great because you will be able to get lots of individualized attention (the classes are very small). Also, the professors are very accessible and the support from other campus services (financial aid, office of the register, exc..) are always prompt and able to resolve most issues in one trip.
cons: The city is very small: there is not very much to do here and if you want more than Walmart you will have to travel two hours or so. Additionally due to the small size of the school there are a lot of just awful teachers for the low level entry classes, making learning difficult.

review_title: Fine when I was there, but things are changing
job_title: Soils Lab Tech in Laramie, WY
pros: My employment at the University of Wyoming was a good experience.  My boss and supervisor were excellent, but things are changing at UW due to server l severe budget issues.  The state's budget crisis is being felt by all state agencies,  and the university is no exception.
cons: The pay system is a massive pain.  You report your hours twice a month,  and then don't get paid for them until two weeks later.  If you start working on the first day of the month toy won't get paid for a full month.

pros: The benefits were great, but the amount they pay out for retirement, etc. probably isn't sustainable. So, although I was grateful for my 403b, etc., I was consistently concerned that I was going to lose my job because the university was pretty irresponsible with funds.
cons: My job was unnecessary and a waste of time. The budget in our department hadn't been balanced in about 5 years, and no one had ever been held accountable for it. I worked with some really great teachers and educators who cared about their jobs (and some who didn't at all), but the organization as a whole needs a kick in the pants. Large organizations that don't balance their budgets end up having to lay people off because things get out of control.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist, Executive in Laramie, WY
pros: Great benefits and flexibility are the greatest reasons to work at UW.  The people are warm and friendly and Laramie's proximity to outdoor recreation and Ft. Collins/Denver makes the location ideal.
cons: Insufficient staffing creates job stress.  Although UW offers its employees one free class per semester the inordinate work load prevents many employees from taking advantage of this benefit.  Different areas on campus (schools, departments) have very little interaction unless they work closely together. It would be nice to see the administration foster more interaction between the different areas on campus.

review_title: Great institution, very well managed and supported by the state.
job_title: Manager of A Grant Funded Program in Laramie, WY
pros: Excellent colleagues, forward thinking environment.  Facilities are first class as is the quality of the workforce.  The students are some of the best I've been exposed to.  Decent benefits, and excellent flexibility in work schedules.
cons: Salaries have been flat for nearly 5 years due to economic downturn.  Although the legislature has finally passed a budget that includes some increases, the overall impact of the "no raises" has been that we've begun to loose talented people, especially researchers and support staff.  Salaries do not compare well to other regional institutions.

review_title: great town, great university, windy as heck
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Laramie, WY
pros:
Wyoming is as cold and windy as you've heard, but UWyo is an inviting and engaging place to work.
*helpful, friendly people
*beautiful campus
*small town, Western feel
*good benefits for staff
*nice gym, even for non-students
*helpful, responsive IT department
*coffee, banking, other amenities right on campus
cons:
*cold, windy, icy in the winter
*battling students to find parking if you don't want to buy a parking permit
*lack of centralization, so you have to find the right person to help you
*state legislation bungling the budget, so university has been making steep cuts

pros: The University of Wyoming is a great place to study and work. Experience might vary depending on different departments, at least I love my department. Professors and students are friendly. I am well funded and I gained a lot of experience at my research group. You can find almost all the resources you need for your research.
cons: The University of Wyoming is a little isolated, so it won't be easy for job searching. Also, the weather here can be harsh on some people, especially during winter (and winter is long).

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Grad School tuition was paid for, so it was a good gig, very flexible time, interesting work, lots of cultural events, and sports.  Though low cost of living does make it better than most schools living situations.
cons: The pay is dirt low, there are zero benefits, their is no unemployment insurance paid, so when your done working, their is no soft landing.  Generally your expected to be in the lab full time.

review_title: It is flexible and convenient but boring.
pros: Great for students can schedule your own hours and read while waiting for people to pick up the phone. It is nice that you can cancel three days before with no penalty as well.
cons: Not the most fun job in the world. It can get boring if you do not have a book or something else to do while dialing. Seems difficult to get promoted. Sometimes shifts get cancelled last minute or you end up working for just an hour.

pros: Uniquely positioned school that has the resources and backing of the entire state (the only four-year-college/university in the entire state); as a result they seem to truly value talent and committed people. A gorgeous location, particularly for those into outdoors life style year around. Extremely respectful and gracious students, many of whom are first generation. Very rewarding to teach these kids
cons: Budget cuts are a perennial thing that severely hamper salary increases, lay offs, and all sorts of cots cutting. Research funding has been cut for years...Not really big cons to say about this place...  It's pretty decent

review_title: I like University of Wyoming as my employer because..
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: It is located in a small friendly city of Laramie. It may not have malls, lighted strips, and plethora of entertainment but you get everything here in Laramie to raise a family and sustain a peaceful life. The University provides a multicultural diversity with students and faculties from all over the world. While working at the university is not very stressful, employees thrives professionally in a relatively easier work environment.
cons: The winter is long and brutal at times. Frequently the access to the city through I-80 gets disrupted due to winter storm.

review_title: Great student job source to earn some easy income
pros: Really easy simple jobs. Can often study/do homework while at job post.
cons:
Have to makeup being interested in "becoming a leader" if you say you're interested in the benefits they automatically black list you.
Some bureaucratic rules like if need repairman, can't directly call repairman instead have to call repair man's dispatcher but if that person out then stuff stays out of service until next day.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: As a research assistant, you have to work under the supervision of your advisor. So, your work experience will largely depend on the person you are working for. Most of the faculties in Mechanical department are very helpful, so the personal and professional growth as a student is very likely to happen.
cons: Currently the university is going under some budget cut. As the research fund is not very promising, the professors usually have small research groups. Some may miss the opportunity to work in a large group here.

review_title: Challenging with lots of opportunity for creativity
job_title: Associate Extension Educator in Laramie, WY
pros: Lots of opportunity to follow your areas of interest, work on projects you are passionate about,   and get involved in the community.  Opportunity to take on leadership roles and participate in professional development. Lots of flexibility.
cons: Lack of direction. You really need to be a self starter, independent, and confident. If you aren't good at planning and saying no, or even if you are, you can spend all your time working.

pros: The immediate supervisors (up to and including the librarian) are fantastic.  Co-workers were historically pretty great too.  Right on campus, so you can run from class to work without much problem.
cons: The pay is quite low (though about as high as you'll find as a student on campus), and the hours are awful.  You will work until midnight (one during finals).  You will eventually open at 0730.  You will work weekends.  On the plus side, your class schedule will be accommodated.

job_title: Programmer Analyst Executive in Laramie, WY
pros: Fantastic benefits, employer contributes a large amount to retirement and encourages continuing education by providing free classes to employees, pay is reasonable for government institutions.  Good culture and values, strong feeling of job security.
cons: Too many layers of middle management in some departments, which causes things to move much more slowly than they should.  The hiring process takes a long time, and anything that requires a decision from upper management usually has to go through multiple meetings for approval.

review_title: My experience has provided and given me an opportunity to learn and grow as person and as a top notch employee.
job_title: Office Support Specialist in Cheyenne, WY
pros: Learned how to multitask, learned how to set priorities, learned how to create systems for myself and learned how to meet deadlines and keep up with a steady work flow.
cons: Working for a leadership who came in and ripped us apart and changed our departments way of work.

pros: The location isn't for everyone, but if small town life in a college town in this area of the country is where you want to be, then a job here provides good work/life balance.
cons: The current climate of the state economy, and the lack of many opportunities for advancement, make for a very constrictive environment.

review_title: I had a very good experience working at the university of Wyoming as a technician for the IT department.
pros: Working in the IT gets you access to some places and experiences troubleshooting a wide range of problems. You get to gain people skills as well
cons: As a student, it can be challenging because a lot of students and faculty have problems and you are so supposed to help so every time you are clocked on you will mostly be busy helping someone.

pros: Very flexible supervisors and accommodated for my school schedule while I worked there. The pay is good too for a student.
cons: High turn over with employees. Upper management was unresponsive and didn't listen to employees ideas or opinions.

pros:
Benefits are really great (it is a state job)
I love working with the student population
It's one of the biggest companies in Laramie
cons:
Many people are unhappy working here
They remove jobs and expect everyone to pick up all the pieces with no additional incentives/pay
The Board of Trustees makes rash decisions and leadership is severely lacking. Having so many university presidents in such a short period does not reflect well on us.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Highlands Ranch, CO
pros:
Good Benefits
Great Coworker and direct supervisor was wonderful.
Loved the work and the ability to jump in and learn new things.
cons: Some of the groups in IT where over worked. The hiring freeze was really confusing. The under management were nice at time but can be ruthless and mean at other times. The management had problems properly explaining things at times or put it on another group at the university to do so.

review_title: My time as a graduate student
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: The theoretical work at the University of Wyoming, particularly in the Petroleum Engineering program, is some of the best currently being performed in the world.
cons: The job market for petroleum engineers hasn't been great since 2014, and the department doesn't recruit companies well enough to give UW students and edge in the job market.

review_title: Love what I do, not the enviroment
pros: I feel like I have a purpose in helping the community and the benefits are good.
cons: There is a major lack of communication both with the overall university and individual departments. This causes an excess of stress and frustration.

pros: All most everybody there is kind and nice. Good salary and benefits, very helpful staff. The university has good funding.
cons: 1) Some employees have problems to understand, spend lots lot time to explain and some people still cannot understand. I believe it's not about their attitude. 2) Some graduate students are under too much pressure from their advisors.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Laramie, WY
pros:
easy to get on high end instruments when everything is up and running, don't have to work in the middle of the night like other schools where equipment is always crowded. Often walk on access to TEM, SEM, XPS, XRD etc.

compensation was above average for living costs and national postdoc salaries.
cons: bureaucracy is bad, they need to streamline their management badly.

pros: Very flexible job for students who are wanting to work and make some money but also focus on school. Staff is great to work with and they are very understanding that school comes first.
cons: Monotonous work, a lot of data entry that requires you to stare at computers for a long period of time.

review_title: I have had a positive experience working for the University of Wyoming.
pros: Very collegial atmoshphere.  Great facilities with the latest technology.  Great opportunities to attend events associtated with a university ie. plays, concerts, sports, lectures, etc.
cons: The state government has frozen salaries for the past four years.  The staff and faculty have not received even cost of living raises since 2009.

pros: Friendly, easy going atmosphere. Easy to get help when needed. Everyone is very passionate about their work.
cons: Terrible pay. Raises are rare and when they do come they are a joke. No career here just a stagnant job. high turnover rate due to these three factors.

job_title: Computer Support Specialist in Laramie, WY
pros: Flexibility, winter break, professional development, casual work environment, interaction with students.  Laramie is a nice, small college town with a friendly atmosphere and lots of opportunity for outdoor activities.
cons: There really aren't many cons to working at the University of Wyoming.  Salaries aren't competitive with private sector but that is to be expected.

job_title: Graduate Student Researcher in Laramie, WY
pros: Cheap tuition and good access to scholarships / funding. Cost of living in Laramie is extremely low and the town has more going on than you might imagine. Good place to study and graduate with little debt.
cons: State budget funds much of the University, and can fluctuate wildly in conjunction with coal and nat. gas revinues.

job_title: Assistant Research Scientist in Laramie, WY
pros: It's first a nice town to live and people here are very nice. Professors are happy to help you with anything.
cons: It is too dry here. The winter is very long. Usually, starts from October to next April.

review_title: Small museum with lots of heart
pros: Small museum, intimate staff. Ability to work on a diverse array of projects. Excellent for gaining direct experience in a number of areas (museum studies, exhibit curation, fossil preparation, tours, education, outreach). Always a need for volunteers or part-time staff.
cons: Due to budget constraints, not much room for professional growth or promotion.

review_title: My experience here at the University of Wyoming has been exceptional!
pros:
Superb work environment
Excellent health benefits
State retirement benefits
Great community
Traffic - None
Like working in a park
Close to activities in larger communities
Far enough away from larger communities to enjoy small town life
cons:
It does get very cold
Nearest neighboring town is 45 miles away
Legislature controlled salary caps
Limited campus parking availability

pros:
Great people in the IT department.  I would recommend it to anyone looking at getting into IT.

Most of the clients were also quite understanding and easy to work with.
cons: The pay isn't the best.  They have wage freezes where no one gets a raise.

pros: Great benefits—vacation, health insurance, employee tuition waiver, holidays, etc.!
cons: Pay is TERRIBLE! It's not competitive with the rest of the nation, and right now, UW is in a financial crisis.

pros: Benefits, type of work (sometimes)
cons: Constantly bullied and harassed by upper management. No leadership, poor pay, nonexistent careers. Pay is well under national average. Extremely hard to leave in this town due to poor pay. If offered a job elsewhere, will take without hesitations. Work working environment. Staff is treated like dirt by management.

job_title: Doctoral Graduate Student in Laramie, WY
pros: Nice university environment. Undergraduate institution. A lot of research funding opportunities via internal grants since this is the only land grant university in the state.
cons: It is located in a small town. So not many opportunities in and around for jobs after graduation. Doesn't have a dedicated graduate school.

review_title: Changes at UW are breaking its back.
job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Laramie, WY
pros: Autonomy in projects once funding is secured.
cons: Unresponsive research office personnel. A house cleaning of all staff is needed. They are a support unit that offers little if any. More often obstruction than assistance.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: STEM graduate assistantships at the University of Wyoming generally provide a monthly stipend, health insurance and tuition waiver. Select an advisor whom you can work and communicate well with and you will have an excellent graduate student experience.
cons: Limited graduate level coursework offered for Fisheries and R Programming.

pros: Great co-workers and leadership. They are flexible around your schedule- school and life. Everyone there truly wants you there and is grateful for your work. It is also a great resume builder.
cons: The pay is really low- but it helps pay some bills!

review_title: A good option for grad school
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Excellent Faculty in Mechanical and Electrical Engineering Department, Vibrant Campus Culture, Grad Students are looked after fairly well
cons: Small Town, Small University,Some archaic processes and lack of interdisciplinary research

review_title: It has been amazing experience to work in academic research
pros:
It has been the best experience working in a small town.
People are very friendly here.
cons:
Winters in Laramie can be unbearable 
Preference of promotion and new openings are given to locals.

review_title: It is a great place to work as a student. They work with your class schedule and give you great leadership opportunities
pros: Flexible, Understanding, Reasonable pay, Great supervisors, great work culture, builds leadership
cons: Not extremely high pay, random hours, must give up some saturdays, chaotic, you must be flexible

pros: Friendly town, University people are very helpful. If you are savvy Wyoming will provide you the opportunities to be a great teacher or a researcher or both
cons: Registrar's office are little bit of a night mare, but it has been getting better over the years

pros: Decent insurance, steady base pay.
cons: The department I'm in. Rotating shift work. High turnover rate. Manager has poor communication and is quick to throw people under the bus. The "Sr." Is hostile and threatens employees. People aren't getting paid their overtime for months after working it.

review_title: Awesome flexible job as a student
job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: I loved making my own hours around my school schedule, I liked being able to advance by taking competency quizzes, and my boss was the nicest human being I have ever met.
cons: Pay is not the greatest, but benefits outweigh this tremendously.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Good people around.  Job satisfaction depends on the department and faculty you work for.
cons: Weather is challenging.  Also compensation depends on the department.  Some are as high as 25000/year, but most of the department pay base salary.

review_title: Good PhD education for the price
pros: Good pay for the cost of living in Laramie, included education expenses and insurance.
cons: The university of very dedicated to underperforming sports teams, loads of money is diverted to those teams and is siphoned from grant money obtained in every educational department.

pros:
Everyone is nice and friendly
Set your own hours around your class schedule
Good resume booster while in school and good office experience
cons:
Not a lot of pay
The occasional customer is rude, some sales problems.
Car not required but you really need one, lots of walking involved.

pros: The town is great. And the commute (walking for most people) is fantastic. It varies for department to department but mine is spectacular.
cons: Recent state budget cuts are putting a squeeze on all levels. Good staff and scientists are leaving and this will just continue.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: It as great campus with really nice people. Laramie is a really cool place too.
cons: The budget cuts are killing the college. The need a better way of dealing with it then gutting the academics.

review_title: Good pay, Good job, Bad aministration
pros: Great work satisfaction, sufficient pay
cons: Payroll would frequently not pay on time or sometimes not pay. I would have to call them and straighten it out way more often than I should. There are many problems like this with the administration

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: The most important reason for me to work here is the assistanship opportunity that UW provides for master students.
cons: Laramie is versy small town and there are not muh to do in the city. In addition to that, weathere is very cold.

pros: Excellent place to work, works around your schedule for school and very nice management team.
cons: Low pay, but obviously with such a turnover it's understandable that it cannot be much higher.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: The university seems to be invested in the students. Many recruitment events. Great opportunity for a work-life balance with outdoor recreation all around the town.
cons: Small town (con if you are used to living in a larger city). Relatively lower pay.

job_title: Group Fitness Instructor in Laramie, WY
pros: Great staff, fantastic facility, and good professional development
cons: Technology level is not up to date and high turnover due to mostly student instructors

pros: The university is very easy going on schedules and is always supporting its employees in seeking new possibilities.
cons: The upper management can be somewhat uncaring and see its part-time employees as replaceable. The communication chain is very short and selective.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Great stipend and work environment. Opportunities to do a lot of different research.
cons: The university has a large focus on energy and so most of the research is energy related. Not a problem if thats what you're in to.

review_title: Good place to work as a student
job_title: After Hours Agent in Laramie, WY
pros: it help me along the line towards my degree and achieving my goals
cons: Working at the IT Department will broaden you knowledge

pros:
Friendly, dedicated faculty members and professionals
Good resources
cons: due to state budget cut, university is letting some people go

pros: Great people. Great atmosphere. They do a great job at the university for making up for the lack of community around the city.
cons: Isolated. Lower pay than most people need to live there.

pros: The university of Wyoming provided flexible scheduling, and did not require me to work weekends
cons: The only con I can think of is the hiring freeze currently in place and the crazy budget cuts.

job_title: Food Prep, Cook, Server, Cashier in Laramie, WY
pros: The team has been really friendly and work environment was always fun and positive.
cons: There have not been any issues during my term of working.

pros:
-Understanding and competent individuals
-Friendly atmosphere
-Decent pay for work duties
-Great work while going to school
cons:
-Sometimes very monotonous
-no real career ladder
-Benefits are lacking

job_title: Office Assistant Senior in Laramie, WY
pros: The typical college campus stuff
cons: UW pays support staff next to nothing and gives no raises.  This year, first raise 6 years and our contribution to retirement and health insurance increased.

review_title: Not a bad place to work while going to school
pros: People were easy to work with, and flexible when it came to scheduling.  Also had training sessions to improve our work.
cons: The pay was very low

review_title: I have enjoyed my time working at the University...
pros:
-Good pay for the job being performed
-Flexible schedule
- Nice people and great opportunities
cons:
- Sometimes a bit disorganized
- Government beauracracy can be a little tedious at times

pros: Good benefits, great facilities, worthy goals and good people, many educational and enrichment benefits.
cons: politicized and favoritism, shoestring budgets, lack of clear strategic goals and accountability

pros: Had a great supervisor Taryn Wright who was empathetic and super amazing! She always pushed me to a better person.
cons: The pressure to work more form above department

review_title: I am a current phD candidate in Chemistry department. I am designing synthetizing new solid state materials.(Carbides)
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Laramie is a nice place to stay in.
cons: Winter is quite tough for most people.

pros: Salary and Benefits good for Wyoming
cons: Administration is sociopathic and lazy

pros: Flexible hours and a good work environment and culture
cons: No opportunities for raises if working in food service

job_title: Programmer Analyst Senior in Laramie, WY
pros: Great benefits, pay, atmosphere, work-life balance. You must work here!
cons: None at all. As mentioned above: Great benefits, pay, atmosphere, work-life balance. You must work here!

pros: Decent pay, good benefits, beautiful campus
cons: Culture is like a high school drama class.  Infighting is immensely problematic in departments.

pros: kind people, flexible, interesting, and engaging
cons: I can't think of any cons! It's a great job to have if you're looking for part-time employment while going to school.

job_title: Accounting Associate, Senior in Laramie, WY
pros: Wonderful campus,supportive leadership. Just love the cowboys!
cons: Parking nothing close and employees have buy own pass not reimbursed.

review_title: very satisfying, fun, flexible, and an overall good experience
job_title: Food Service Worker in Laramie, WY
pros: flexible with your schedule, on campus
cons: sometimes give you bad hours

pros: Great location, lots of recreational activity availability.
cons: Wages are stagnant or sinking.  Lack of raises going on the 7th year, potential cuts to teaching staff are very worrisome.

pros: Laramie is a great place to live. There are jobs for graduate students.
cons: Cost of living is high but jobs in Laramie typically pay lower than the national average.

review_title: A good job for a full-time student
pros: Good variety of hours to choose from and decent pay compared to other employers in Laramie.
cons: Pay is still fairly low.

review_title: Great experience, complete growth opportunity for graduating students along with the education
pros: Room to work your ideas and not very demanding.
cons: little more interaction with different departments will be great.

pros: Full funding for an year.
cons: Depends on instructor. Sometimes they can be a pain. Unnecessary make up labs

review_title: Great Work Culture and Flexible Hours
pros:
-Highly educated supervisors/bosses
-They work with you on scheduling
-Open minded and nondiscriminatory environment
-Worthwhile research/data projects
cons: -Pay is reasonable but not high

pros: Great culture, good money, freedom
cons: Poor supervisor, strange choice for University President

review_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Zoology and Physiology Department
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Laramie, WY
pros: Diverse faculty, small campus but plenty of resources
cons: Isolated city but great if you like outdoor activities

pros: It is a very good school
cons: I know of no downsides besides it has difficult accessibility in the winter

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Laramie, WY
pros: Most friendly people to work with, specially the boss
cons: nothing specific. everything was nice except to get an apartment near campus

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Very accessible and approchable faculty.
cons: Admisnistration and office staff not efficient.

pros: easy to meet the requirements

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Laramie, WY
pros: Flexible work schedule, great coworkers, great time to study for class
cons: There's nothing negative I can say

pros: The university of Wyoming provides a good deal of support to everything
cons: Graduate Assistant salary is quite low.

pros: Great collaborations and technical equipment available across departments

pros: It's a very diverse and fun community

pros: Job Security , Easy going , Work life Balance

pros: Cohesive group of students and staff with good funding opportunities.

pros: Nice professors nice environment to study

pros: Great environment, great people, great benefits.
